ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FLOOD-PREVENTION MEASURES
(LOW-LYING AREAS)


    1. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Communications and Works, in view of the approach of the rainy season, whether all flood-prevention measures in the low-lying areas have now been completed; and whether he can give an assurance that experience in the past, particularly in the Bedok Resettlement area and in the Kampong Tai Seng area near the Paya Lebar Airport, will not be repeated.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I regret that I have to give a negative reply to both parts of the question. I expect that the hon. Member and the House in general would like to have more than a bare negative on this matter. I will therefore go into some detail so that the hon. Member can understand the scientific complexities of the problem of flood prevention.

    In my reply to a similar question last July, I indicated that there were two factors which prevent rapid and immediate action against flooding. First, it is necessary to undertake lengthy hydrological and topographical surveys

Column: 794

to ascertain the exact causes and nature of flooding in each area where it occurs. Since all subsequent flood prevention measures must be based on these preliminary surveys, it is necessary that the survey should be completely accurate in order that mistakes can be avoided and public money should not be wasted. There is thus a considerable time factor involved between the occurrence of a flood and the taking of measures to prevent its recurrence.

    There is also a cost factor which is very serious. Preliminary investigations indicate that for the city area alone, flood prevention works might cost as much as $60 million. Expenditure of that nature must obviously be balanced against other necessary public expenditure, and if it were to be undertaken, it would deserve the most serious and careful study by all Members of the Assembly.

    The hon. Member may better understand the nature of the problem if I tell him that it is essentially one of scientific control of vast natural forces. In this particular island of Singapore, it is complicated by the fact that the natural forces were not sufficiently taken into account in the earlier development of the island.

    I should like to assure the hon. Member that the Government is acutely aware of the suffering and the waste which result from recurrent flooding. I personally had experience of this in past years; it is a problem that frequently recurs to my mind. Any attempt, however, to deal with the problem of flooding on a vote-catching basis of temporary measures, stop-gap measures, would do little good and almost certainly involve a considerable waste of public money. We must proceed scientifically in this matter if we are to get any useful result.

    The second part of the hon. Member's question is partly answered already, but I will give some further details. He mentions the Bedok Resettlement area. I shall make a statement later in connection with a Report that has been tabled. It is enough to say now that the bund has been strengthened and the drainage channel has been straightened and deepened.

Column: 795



    I may also mention that the City Council has undertaken a number of minor flood prevention works at the Stamford/Orchard Canal, Bukit Timah/ Rochore Canal, Sungei Whampoa, Sungei Kallang, Geylang Serai and Geylang River, and in the Ulu Pandan area. At Kampong Tai Seng to which the hon. Member refers, the flood problem arises from the low-lying nature of the land, and the problem may have been increased to some extent by agricultural development. The Chief Drainage Engineer will be recommending measures for Kampong Tai Seng as soon as his investigations have been completed.

    The hon. Member will see, therefore, that though it is scientifically impossible to give him the assurance he asks for, hard work has been done to assess the need and to recommend measures for flood control. I may add a final word of comfort. Meteorologically speaking, the probability of flooding on last year's scale is rather small. Records show that the daily rainfall at Kallang on the 9th and 10th December, 1954, has only been exceeded once in the last 72 years; and similarly the total monthly rainfall at Kallang last December was the highest for 86 years. We can hope that we shall not have two record years of flooding in immediate succession.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister for Communications and Works give an assurance that requests for deepening of channels be taken in hand as soon as possible, in view of possible flooding due to the monsoon that is about to break in a month's time?

    Mr Francis Thomas: I have already dealt with this, Mr Speaker, Sir, in my answer to the first question. Whatever can be done will be done. It is no use going ahead until you are able to have a scientific assessment of the problem. You can transfer the water from one area to another without getting it off the land and into the sea.

SINGAPORE TRACTION COMPANY STRIKE


    2. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether he will give a detailed report on

Column: 796

the present strike of the Singapore Traction Company employees; and state what steps have been taken by the Government to settle this dispute and relieve the public from this inconvenience.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, in July this year the Singapore Traction Company Employees Union submitted demands relating to increase in wages and improved conditions of service for all employees in the Company. The management replied that they were unable to entertain these demands from the Union, as they were in violation of an agreement signed between the management and the Union in February 1954. This agreement was binding on both parties and precluded either party from submitting or entertaining fresh demands relating to terms and conditions of employment for a period of two years.

    On 12th September a 14-day strike notice was submitted by the Union to the management. During this period the Labour Department contacted both parties, who agreed to a joint meeting. At this meeting the management stated that they would be prepared within a week to begin negotiations on a new agreement to be effective from 1st January, 1956. The Union, however, stated that negotiations should commence immediately and that any revised wage rates should become effective from 14th July, 1955, the date on which the original demands were submitted. The management offered to refer the question of the validity of the agreement to the Attorney-General. This was rejected by the Union.

    On 26th September the 14-day strike notice expired and resulted in a complete stoppage of buses run by the Singapore Traction Company. Since that date Government has maintained contact with both parties with a view to seeking a means of resuming negotiations on an effective basis so as to bring the dispute to an early settlement.

    Following the arrival of the Chairman of the Singapore Traction Company, Sir Thomas Strangman, the parties met again yesterday in the Labour Ministry.

Column: 797

The Union urged that the management should reconsider their stand on the previous agreement in view of the recent wage increases in other bus companies. The Union also contended that the Singapore Traction Company's wage policy tended to encourage corruption among conductors. The management, however, were not prepared to modify their stand on the sanctity of the agreement previously entered into by the Committee of the Union and endorsed by a general meeting of members. The meeting, Sir, therefore ended in a deadlock.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Government approve of agreements -

    Mr Speaker: Order. Will the hon. Member address his supplementary question to the Minister?

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: As you please, Mr Speaker. Does the Minister for Labour approve of agreements in which unions are bound for an indefinite period regardless of drastic changes in surrounding circumstances?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, it is a question of freedom of contract. It was not the Government which advised the Union to enter into such an agreement.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: But do you approve it?

    Mr M. P. D. Nair: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister say whether there is any truth in the Singapore Traction Company Employees Union's claim that the employers themselves have violated the agreement?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, according to my knowledge, the employers have denied that there has been that claim that they have violated the agreement themselves.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is the Minister aware that subsequent to the signing of this agreement, there were, to use a neutral word, departures from the particular clause in this agreement prohibiting or preventing either party from varying the terms of the agreement?

PAN-MALAYAN ECONOMIC WORKING PARTY VISIT TO INDONESIA
(Statement by the Chief Minister)


    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to inform hon. Members that, as a follow up of the goodwill mission and in furtherance of this Government's policy of promoting good neighbourly relations and stimulating the flow of trade, a Pan-Malayan Economic Working Party, under the leadership of my friend and colleague the Assistant Minister for Commerce and Industry, the Hon. Mr J. M. Jumabhoy, was in Indonesia from the 3rd to the 10th of October.

    I am happy to announce that it received from the Indonesian Government a courteous and friendly reception, and negotiations indicated an equally sincere desire on the part of the Indonesian Government for friendly understanding and healthy trade relationship.

    The report of the Working Party is now under consideration by the respective Governments. One of the principal items is an offer by the Indonesian Government to release immediately 12,000 tons of slab rubber as an exceptional measure to aid our unemployment problem. There is also a possibility of further limited quantities of slab rubber being exported until such time as the Indonesian Government is able completely to implement its policy of inducing the producers to manufacture sheet rubber instead of the far less economical slab rubber.

    I should like to say that I appreciate this friendly and neighbourly gesture on the part of the Indonesian Government. I would add that we have offered our services to Indonesia in carrying out its policy of helping producers to manufacture sheet rubber by facilitating the purchase from this territory of their requirements.

Column: 799



    The Indonesian Government has requested that we should consider taking action to check trade which is illicit under their laws. Within the framework of our free port policy which is essential to our very existence, this Government considers that there is a neighbourly obligation to assist along these lines, and this request will be sympathetically considered in all its implications.

    A further request for extension of payment in United States dollars in respect of produce imported for re-export to hard currency areas will be pursued. It is one of the subjects which I shall discuss with the Colonial Office on my projected visit next December.

    The Indonesian authorities reaffirm that, under the new Indonesian import policy, there are no discriminatory restrictions on imports from Malaya, and that Singapore and Federation merchants will be able freely to quote for regular Indonesian requirements.

    A list of return goods permitted to be carried by fish carriers returning to Rhio and Lingga was received. This list has been a matter of lengthy correspondence and I am happy that agreement has at last been reached.

    It has also been clarified that Malayan/ Indonesian films will in future be exchanged on a basis of equal reciprocity of showing, over and above a quota of seven Malayan films allowed per year.

    We have also received an assurance that there will be no restrictions on imports of salt fish from us, provided the salt fish is of Malayan origin and subject to the pattern of Indonesian trade. This is particularly helpful, Sir, to the fishing industry of Malaya and, to some extent, of Singapore.

    The question of facilitating the issue of visas for businessmen is being actively pursued, and other matters are being investigated in anticipation of the discussions of the Economic Mission. An Indonesian fact-finding mission will be coming to Singapore shortly to study our procedure about the end of this month.

Column: 800



    All items discussed have been set out in the form of an agreed record signed by the leaders of the Working Parties of both sides for confirmation by their respective Governments, and a possible agenda for the Economic Mission has been drawn up.

    We have extended to Indonesia an invitation for its Economic Mission to come to Singapore, at least for the first part of the meeting projected for early January, and are awaiting a reply to this invitation.

    The Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing, my friend and colleague the Hon. Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat, and Sir Sydney Caine pursued enquiries with a view to closer cultural relations, and tentative arrangements have been arrived at as a first step in what is hoped will be ever closer cultural relations with Indonesia.

    I wish to inform hon. Members that in the Working Party there prevailed complete harmony between the Federation representatives and our own, and I desire to thank the Federation for this brotherly co-operation. I also wish to thank the leader and members of the Working Party for their efforts on our behalf, and I would particularly mention Sir Sydney Caine, Mr J. A. D. Morrison, Mr Yap Pheng Geck, Mr D. T. Assomull, Mr L. L. Best, Mr Tan Hock Seng, Mr Kwek Soh Loh, and Mr W. H. McNeil, for their public spirit in giving generously of their time and advice during the negotiations.

    I think it right, Sir, to add a tribute to the spirit in which the Indonesian Government approached the solution of the trading problems between us, and it is my sincere hope that that spirit, which we fully reciprocate, will culminate next January in an agreement that will be the framework for healthy and friendly relations with our neighbours.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chief Minister?

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, would it be appropriate at this juncture to move the adjournment at the rising of the House or -?

REPORT ON THE DRAINAGE OF THE BEDOK AND KETAPANG CATCHMENTS
(Statement by Mr Francis Thomas)


    Mr Francis Thomas: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already referred to the Report on the drainage of the Bedok and Ketapang Catchments which has been tabled. I think the House may be glad to hear what action is being taken. The recommendations of this Report have been accepted by Government, and we are getting on with the necessary work as fast as possible.

    Members will observe, from the last paragraph in the Report, that the first work to be undertaken is the construction of the dam and spillways for the impounding reservoir. Action to acquire the necessary land for this project is now in progress, and work on the reservoir will start as soon as we are entitled to enter on the land. Thereafter the construction of the dam and the erection of the spillways should be completed in about two months, if the weather is not too bad. This means that if we can get possession of the land before the end of this month, a very large measure of protection to the Bedok and Ketapang areas may have been afforded by the end of the year. We can only hope and pray that there will be no abnormally heavy rains before that time.

    Sir, as I mentioned earlier, the bund below the Changi Road has already been raised and strengthened, and the main drainage channel has been straightened and deepened. These measures should give some degree of protection against flooding. The real protection will only be assured when the flood reservoir has been completed. It is unfortunate that large works of this

Column: 802

nature cannot be planned and executed in a few weeks or a few months. It was just not possible to start earlier.

    Members will see from the Report what careful investigation and surveying has to be done before a workable scheme can be formulated. This is particularly the case when there are complicating factors like the coral reef out at sea off the Bedok River outlet which necessitates special measures.

    Members will have noticed that the Report envisages that the area of the impounding reservoir should be used as an open space during the period when it is not holding floodwaters. The City Council has now suggested that the reservoir should be used as a reservoir the whole year round. The City Council Water Engineer believes that it should be possible to get an average of almost two million gallons of water a day from the water impounded in the reservoir. This will be a very useful addition to the water which the City Council expects to get from the wells which are being sunk in the Bedok plain, and this additional water supply is an added justification for spending a considerable sum of money on the drainage scheme and on the necessary land acquisition.

REGISTRATION OF PERSONS BILL
First Reading


    The Chief Secretary (Mr W. A. C. Goode): Mr Speaker, Sir, I present a Bill intituled "An Ordinance to provide for the registration of persons in the Colony, for the issue of identity cards and for purposes connected therewith", and move it be read the First time.

    Bill read the First time.
Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

    Mr Goode: Now, Sir. Mr Speaker, Sir, I have a Certificate of Urgency over the hand of the Governor declaring that it is necessary for this Bill to be proceeded with through all its stages at this morning's sitting of the House.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Have you copies of the Bill?

    Mr Goode: Yes, Sir. Typed copies of the Bill have already been distributed to hon. Members, and thanks to the good offices of the Clerk of the Assembly, I also have the printed copies available, Sir, which I suggest could be distributed.

    Printed copies of the Bill handed in to the Clerk and distributed to hon. Members.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Goode, will you please move the Second Reading?

    Mr Goode: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    I must apologise, Sir, to hon. Members of this House that I was not able to introduce this Bill at our sitting last month and thereby give the House longer time to study the Bill. Unfortunately I was not able to get the Bill ready in time before this morning's sitting, and it has therefore been necessary, Sir, for me to ask the House to proceed with all the stages of the Bill this morning.

Column: 804



    The Bill is short and seeks merely to provide for the continuation of the system of national registration which, as hon. Members will know, is at present governed by some Emergency Regulations, which Regulations will lapse when the period of the Emergency ceases on 21st October.

    I hope, Sir, that this Bill, which is short, will not prove controversial and that Members of this House will agree that the system of identity cards has proved of very real use and assistance to the people of this Colony on all sorts of occasions when they seek an easy means of establishing their identity. I also hope that the House will agree to put this Bill through its stages this morning to enable that system to be continued.

    Regulations will be made to provide for the details, and those Regulations will be substantially the same as the existing system, and I very much doubt whether the ordinary citizen of Singapore will, in fact, notice this formal change which I ask the House to make. I beg to move.

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): I beg to second.

    Question proposed.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are only two points I wish to make. If you look at your identity card, you will find that not only the nationality but also the race of the person has to be filled in. If we are to overcome racial consciousness and racial antagonisms, and if we are to build up a nation, it seems to me that there should be no reference to race on our national registration card. I hope that the Government will look into this matter and see if an early change can be made.

    Secondly, now that it has been decided to continue the identity card system, and this has our full support, I hope that the Government will introduce appropriate rules to see that the Singapore citizens get their identity cards in proper order and their addresses up to date. If we are to have accurate electoral rolls, this is essential.

Column: 805



    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, how very true what the Chief Secretary (Mr Goode) has said, that the average citizen of Singapore would not know that there has been any change! But for us, who are conscious that there has been a change, I think it would not be without value to weigh the significance of that change.

    The identity card was a product of the war, imported from Britain into Singapore at a time when the Government felt that it was in a state of war. It was part and parcel of the Emergency Regulations; one of those irritating restrictions on personal liberties which we hoped would be got rid of as we get rid of the Emergency. But now it is proposed to make it a part of our normal lives. There is not even a pretence of making it last for only a matter of three years. It is an attempt, without too much publicity, to make the identity card part and parcel of our lives. I am not going into the merits of having a national registration system by which social security can be equitably apportioned and all the other useful by-products of having national registration. I do not wish to debate these points. But I wish to point out, as one who, perhaps unrealistically, believes in a liberal way of life, that it is a marked departure from the normal traditions of a liberal civilised society.

    The Chief Minister: You are wrong!

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I am wrong? May I tell the Chief Minister, Mr Speaker, Sir, that one of the first things they were pleased to do in England, some years after the war - because they had got tied up with the identity card system by tying it up with rationing and all the other necessary regulations in a Socialist state - was to abolish the identity card system? A state of affairs was reached where judges refused to convict citizens when they refused to produce their identity cards on the demand of a police officer.

Column: 806



    Sir, one of the evil by-products of this identity card system is that everytime a policeman sees you, he asks, `Teng-kee'? Where is your identity card? " 'Teng-kee manah'?" The unfortunate hawker or pedestrian or cyclist or motorist or lorry-driver begins to look upon this scrap of paper as something which, somehow or the other, gets him down every time.

    There have been spirited citizens in Singapore - and I had the privilege of fighting for some of them - who, for traffic offences, have been asked to produce their identity card. It becomes a habit - a policeman asking you, "I want to see who you are, and I want to 'fix' you! Where is your identity card?" It is not an offence connected with the Emergency. It is not an offence connected with the security of the State. It is just a bad habit. These traffic offenders then have to go to court. The police prosecute and say, "Emergency Regulation so and so, on such a day, so and so demanded the identity card." But the citizen who is keenly aware of his democratic rights refused to produce his identity card. I know of a case in England where a British judge, well-known for his asperity, had refused to convict and had castigated the Police for having abused the identity card system. Sir, this identity card system has got nothing to do with motoring offences and all the other minor things in life. But it has become a habit.

    In Singapore, when I tried to put forward this liberal point of view, I was smacked down very vigorously and told, "This is quite a different world and, therefore, we have quite different standards. Any citizen, even though he has done nothing to warrant a policeman asking for his identity card, must produce it in conformity with the law, and there must be proper respect for the law." So, the spirited citizen, because he was conscious of his fundamental rights, was properly smacked for $25 and asked to behave himself in the future.

Column: 807



    Sir, I hope we are aware that what we are doing today is to accept a system which cannot be defended as democratic. It is not that I am in favour of people going off on lost weekends and not wishing to sign their identity cards on hotel registers; though I think that even such persons should be entitled to certain human liberties and they should not have to put their mark everywhere they go to show that they have been there. "Identity card? - I know mine by heart, because I have signed it so often as 'Four E, 00635'." It is part of the regimentation of a police state, and one of the things we accuse the Communists of doing, that they document people; they regiment them; they get everybody docketed in dossiers. We, in a liberal democracy, believe in liberal conditions. We value human freedom and the liberty of the individual.

    I have not heard sufficient argument debated as to why the social schemes which the Government proposes to introduce could not be done in some way other than by the identity card. It is quite possible that it is a convenient way, but the difference is this: we are now making this identity card part and parcel not only of our lives for the period of the Emergency in Malaya, but part and parcel of our normal lives. This, I am sure the Chief Minister will agree, will not be one of those legislative acts of which he could be proud as a democratic and a liberal humanitarian.

    Mr Francis Thomas: The Member for Tanjong Pagar (Mr Lee Kuan Yew), Mr Speaker, Sir, referred to the identity card as an irritating restriction on personal liberty. I rather agree that all these things are irritating restrictions. They have to be very often, but they have positive advantages. Traffic lights are often exceedingly irritating, as are restrictions about where you can park your car. They are irritating, but, nevertheless, they are necessary for the general flow of the traffic. Identity cards may very well be necessary for the general

Column: 808

running of Singapore. Although the hon. Member says he does not wish to debate the usefulness of the identity card system, I think it is fair to point out, from my personal experience, its usefulness.

    During the floods which took place last year - I have already mentioned them this morning - I was concerned with organising a relief centre at which we had some hundreds of people passing through. The maximum was 900 refugees sleeping in the centre in a single night. We organised large distributions of food, clothing, money, chickens and all sorts of things. All passed through the centre, and for that work (which had to be improvised among largely illiterate people) the identity card was absolutely essential. It was the only possible way of seeing that people pass through the queue once, and not two, three, four or five times. It was also essential for a house-to-house survey. Our survey teams went out and some went through about a thousand households and recorded details; and in order to be sure that there was no confusion of any kind, the identity card was solid documentary evidence; where a Chinese name, spoken by a Hokkien, recorded by a Cantonese, is written down in English, it may become an exceedingly different name and may lead to confusion. Therefore, especially in times of emergency, in my personal experience, the identity card is a most valuable and useful piece of social mechanism.

    The substance of the hon. Member's argument against identity cards was the occasional abuses that occur, that they are troublesome and that sort of thing. Well, the answer to that, I think, is that if abuses occur, they can be remedied, and this Assembly, as I have pointed out before, is the place to remedy them. It is the fashion at the moment in Singapore to run around talking very vigorously in public assemblies - not this Assembly - but in Kampong Tai Seng or in Farrer Park, or wherever it may be, and to put out a lot of highly contentious propaganda which has very little basis in fact, if there is any. In fact, it is sometimes completely contrary

Column: 809

to the facts. That is a way of winning a certain measure of popular support, but it does not affect the law. The place to deal with the law is in the Assembly. The way to deal with any abuse of the law is to bring it to the notice of the Assembly for its joint consideration and action. The fact that abuses may have occurred in the past is an argument for the Assembly to take action to ensure that they do not occur in the future. It is not an argument to throw away a useful part of the social mechanism.

    Mr Goode rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Goode, in reply?

    Mr Goode: In reply, Sir.
